threads.name: Santa Man
threads.com:
It's November 1st, so you know what that means. It's time for /toy/ Secret Santa 2022!

There doesn't appear to be as many shipping delays this year but I'm still making the cut off for sign up November 6th like last year because it worked out well and gives everyone through the weekend to sign up. I will try to have assignments out by the 7th or the 8th at the latest.

There are some small changes to SS this year though:
>The budget has been changed from 25-35 usd to 30-40 usd
>Proof of purchase will now require you to send me a picture of your gift with a timestamp before I give it the ok along with the receipt
>I will not be pairing up Canadians domestically due to issues in the past. Those who wish to ship domestic will be paired with people in the US. Sorry for the inconvenience.

For more info on these changes check the FAQ as I've detailed it there for the exception of the price change because the explanation for that is very simple. I picked out the original 25-35 price range several years ago and after years of running the event I felt bumping the price up by 5 dollars better reflects what people actually spend on the event, that's all.

My email: toysecretsanta2022@gmail.com
Sign-up form: https://forms.gle/yXbEEiFmu8t1xTs77
FAQ: https://pastebin.com/jA4SUZUQ

Where to buy
>GSC Online Shop - some figmas only are available through their online shop
>Amiami - usual place for buying, to some people, shipping is a bit higher due to packaging
>Hobby Link Japan shipping is usual lower, but their prices are a bit higher, private warehaouse is available
>Hobby Search Japan - items stay in stock the longest
>Mandarake - search figma or フィグマ
>eBay/Amazon - only if you hate having too much money. Avoid bootlegs, you can spot them as 'Chinese version'
>http://jungle-scs.co.jp/ - Seems like you can fine some good deals here
>Check the BST threads, My Figure Collection for any offer/deal

This is my first post on /toy/. I just came here to read more about it. I thought that we peaked with the Maverick ten years ago, but the youngins in my family have Trailblazers, and they seem like straight upgrades to the previous revolvers. The plastic on the Trailblazer seems cheaper than usual. That's the only downside.
It's accurate and has good range. It has more rounds in the cylinder and the weight distribution is better. It's easier to operate and you can even fan fire it. If I still had my maverick, I would test them to see how they compare.
Does anyone know if you can replace the springs on them? Cool kids back in my day used to do that. I'd also like to know if fan firing is bad for the guns. It's hard on real revolvers, but until I take one apart, I can't really know how the insides can handle abuse.

>>10149252
I was going to say the X-Shot Reflex but, if he's already got a functionally identical blaster, the Dread/Xcess offers something slightly different. It's still a 6-shot revolver but that orange ring under the trigger allows you to switch to a second cylinder for a quick reload. It also comes in various non-Sonic flavours. It's a shame that the Nerf Raptor Slash has that exact aiming issue you're describing because that would be an easy recommendation to kids otherwise.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10149254
>The plastic on the Trailblazer seems cheaper than usual
Yep, that's Elite 2.0 for you. And the Trailblazer is one of the better E2.0 blasters. There are aftermarket springs for similar blasters available but you can't get much more power out of that system (plus, increasing the spring load on a one-handed blaster will make using it for extended periods painful unless you're the reigning thumb war champion)
>is fan firing bad for the guns
Not as far as I'm aware but you'll likely lose power due to not pulling the hammer back fully. There are third party extended hammers but I don't know if they're compatible with the Trailblazer.

Yeah I'm here. Not sure how you're doing it. I would make a mold first for the bottom, then after it's cold I would make the top part. Also key the molds. I would cut them into squares to it would be easy to align them.

I remember I would also put green stuff on each half and remove the excess, then press both halves and apply some pressure. I think that gave the best results. Also on some parts I added holes at the bottom so the excess green stuff could come out.

Recently I painted the leg I made out of green stuff. I was very impressed with the results. Sadly I didn't sand it first so it had some rough parts. I had to remove the paint (pic related) but never got to paint it again.
Haven't duplicated much else with green stuff since tho.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10149209
You make a compelling case for the toyline ending at the right time, but I feel like the show should have gone on longer.
It was ahead of its time in terms of weaving interesting locales and historical/cultural beliefs and monsters/myths/legends/cryptids into a plot which was accessible to kids, and sought to teach a little bit about different cultures without cramming it down their throats or assuming that the audience was too young or inattentive to learn; it walked a very fine balance between being full of action and suspense, while also showing characters’ inner conflicts and growth arcs. There would also almost always be enough research into the mythos behind each monster/threat of the week that you could learn a lot about different parts of the world during an episode, and even then the writers would still include a brief monologue from Max at the end revealing a few additional historical/mythological inspirations which couldn’t be explored deeper given the constraints of the plot/runtime. It didn’t try to get kids excited about the playsets; it got them excited about the real world.
I’m still not sure how I feel about the ending (it wasn’t bad, and it had to end at some point, but you could tell the writers were backed into a corner by not knowing whether it would be syndicated for another season). If there had been another season, it was primed to incorporate an additional layer of historical exploration with time travel, but since there wasn’t it feels like all anyone takes away from it is “time travel, lazy writing, copout, tripped at the finish line.” None of those things are really true, and it’s sad that the series wasn’t more appreciated in its time amidst the flood of glorified 30-minute toy commercials which predominated the market (which has overall improved but continues to limit investment in highly watched series even today).
I don’t think a revival is the right answer either, though.

last_replies.com: I use Body-chan and kun for some poses that really confuse me (pic related), but really you need to study human anatomy and how it works. People think dolls are a good shortcut to being a better artist, but you aren't learning anything. Drawing freely and thinking 3D helps a lot.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
This dude right here. I can use almost any decent figure to figure out a pose and the foreshortening. Knowing all those attachment points is what really works for a good drawing.

He’s 20 bucks on amazon and i did the greywash myself.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
As a professional artist who's been doing this for a decade plus at this point, you don't buy a figure. None of them properly display things like musculature or really do anything than give you a basic idea and starting point. There's a reason that the classical drawing figure is basic shapes. If you need or want more than that, don't spend money on getting some figure that'll still not do what you actually need it to do when you don't have anatomical knowledge.
Pirate or buy CSP and use the 3d models as a basis. You can either use them for reference on a separate canvas or trace over them. You can adjust lighting direction and intensity, focus and perspective, change proportions and have control over as many bones as you could generally want in a 3d model for this kinda thing. It's far easier and better than any figure I've ever had for reference and you can also stick it into other 3d environments as well as apply objects to the character and said environments.

>>10150920
This is also one of the only useful things in this regard, because it lets you quickly check where and how muscles sit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Been collecting for about 10 years and my revelation was, setting goals for my collection. Break that down to specific figure lines. Can you have a full display with all the characters? A simple display with 2 really detailed statues of a bigger scale? A cool army looking array with a bunch of smaller figures? Smaller size lines are easier collected and displayed.

It just all depends on what you want and can envision your collection looking like, without it seeming overwhelming. Try to envison or plan what the actual size of different displays would be like. Simplifying and streamlining is important. If youre not big on a series why not just get the 2-4 main characters and then write the collection for that property "complete". When you have an end goal it makes it easier to say, ok, the collection for ___ is done now. of course new figures will always come out, but then you can make small replacements or exceptions. This is what helps me at least in getting rid of shit and making room for new stuff, as well as having a bigger picture for how all these figures will come together.

I agree with the above poster, White Noise is probably objectively the best.

I will also submit a side vote for Ricochet. Since I was a kid I specifically wanted a super articulated boxing kangaroo figure, and somewhat improbably, that's exactly what I got some ~15 years later. This mold is great fun, with much better range of motion than I was expecting. The little joey (who is apparently the one actually named Ricochet, the kangaroo is just his mech suit) can be stored away in the belly, and has rudimentary articulation himself. The boxing gloves and visor are also removable if you want a "plain" robot kangaroo.

The only downside is I remember the transformation being kind of too complex and fiddly to be fun. I say "remember" because I had a bad time with it the first time, and haven't transformed it since. It's truly amazing as a figure, but if you're looking for one that's fun to transform back and forth repeatedly, this might not be the one.

The time has come for us to finally have new releases in the line! By now most of everyone who ordered Olivier and Vania should have them in hand. As of now, we only have one other figure up for Pre-Order right now, that being Bikini Clover. Currently we know that the Polynian and Touhou series will continue since Marisa is supposedly the next in line to go up. The official Poly 4Koma is still going and it seems its been well received as it gives little look into the everyday lives of the Polys we know. Nice job anon! Contrary to what plamo general says it's completely fine to paint on bare plastic and top coat all that. On that topic, I'd advice you to paint details before glosscoat, because then you can scratch excess paint off of the model. Looking at that front skirt piece, I get what you were going for there, but the edges of the red area could've been trimmed using something like a cocktail stick for a sharper end result. Same goes for the panel lines.
Plamo general is a good source of inspiration but they'll grill you for not painting 100% of the kit. But you just do your own thing and have fun anon.

Speaking of ranks, I started taking pics of each of my individual armies because it's hard to see each figure in a group of 90 of em. Starting with my smallest, and kind of newest faction, the Cult of Poxxus.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10144045
There are official goods on there, but they cost so much there's no incentive to buy them there over any other store. It's mainly an advantage to people living in China.

The low cost of KOs is a big plus, especially with Transformers where "US seller" on eBay means "I'm charging 3x" & a lot of collectors rarely sell their 3P or KOs. It's also a bonus for knockoff Skytube figures, where i can take a 5% drop in quality & lose things like magnets when I'm now paying $15-$25 for a statue instead of the absurd $200+ for the official ones.

The major downside to AE is that any problems with orders are a massive pain in the ass to correct. Sellers rarely want to send replacement parts from their own stock, they prefer to contact the company for parts, which means up to a month to get a replacement piece- if the company isn't out of business.

It's also harder for AE sellers to defraud you, but still possible, so look up guides for the common scams. I've had some sellers bend over backwards to be helpful, but a few tried to pull blatant scams. Generlaly if they offer to refund you & they'r elegit they'll tell you to open a claim & request a partial refund. If they offer to send it to you by Paypal & bypass the claim system, expect them to file INR on the funds after a few weeks because YOU never sent THEM anything.

>>10139050

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10138805
to list a few:

1) No one-brain-brick gui, only a bunch of LEDs, even the original RCX had a way to select programs.

2) Teal can be hard to integrate with existing collections to make something that looks cohesive.

3) Has 6 ports instead of 7 like the previous version, and while the RCX only had 3 ports, you could stack motors on a single port.

4) Worse specs, it runs at 100mhz, with room for 30 programs and 32mb of storage, while the previous version was 300mhz (and could be overclocked to 400mhz) and had an SD card slot.

5) cables are permanently connected to the motors and sensors, meaning if any part of that cable gets damaged you have to replace the entire thing.

6) No backwards compatability, Ev3 could use NXT motors (but not sensors), and there were first and third party adapters adapters for RCX motors, and the new one is incapable of using any of these.

7) A somewhat more minor issues, but it comes with a 4th motor instead of a touch sensor, severely limiting capabilities out of the box.


All in all, it's pretty crap.

We had a really comfy LOTR toys thread here a while ago. As said before, the original line from 2001-2005 still holds up really well, especially some of the later figures when Toybiz started moving away from action gimmicks to 30POA (they're essentially Marvel Legends style figures), and they're actually still quite affordable to collect, with a few exceptions (the Balrog).

There's not really a lot of new stuff to talk about with LOTR toys although Diamond Select did just come out with their 8" deluxe figures. There's no toys for "that show" and there probably won't be (good riddance). Once in a while it's nice to have a thread to catch up on how fellow LOTR anons' collections are going though. What scenes do you want to recreate? Are you army building? Doing any customs and conversions to complete your collection? Have you come across any cool boomer LOTR merch from before the movies? Let's take a moment to celebrate that this beloved book series got the action figure line it deserved.
